content.description:
Begin as for

Agnes

and where that route breaks right stay left along a crack that narrows to a seam leading to the top.

* There is a bit of a run-out at the crux which while potentially exciting is safe.
content.protection:
Gear to 2 inches with an emphasis on thin gear, especially wires; bolted anchors shared with

Stellar Arete
content.location:
Located between

Stellar Arete

and

Agnes

.

content.description:
An aptly named and classic route.

A boulder problem start guards the arete proper, once at the second bolt the climb takes on its true character and the moves to the third bolt provide a taste (albeit on good holds) of what is to come. The moves past bolts three, four, and five provide exciting and tenuous laying-away on the edge of the arete with somewhat grainy footholds, but somehow the clips always go well.

Pull up onto a ledge, clip the last bolt and surmount the final step to a wonderful view down the valley to the lake.

If this were at HVP there would be a line to climb this one.
content.location: The left edge of the right tower, rather obvious.

climbs.name: Observatory
climbs.fa: Brad Singer and Eric Odenthal, May 2001

content.description:
A delicate route that climbs a flake to thin face and finishes up a distinct left-slanting arete.

When you get to the top of the route look for it's namesake which is visible on the northern shore of Big Bear Lake.
content.location:
Located just left of

Hy-Pro-Glo

on a separate detached portion of pinnacle.

content.description: Fun climbing to a narrow ledge and then thin edges up a nice lichen splashed face with a distinct crux at about the halfway mark.
content.location:
Just left and around the corner from

Stellar Arete

.

content.description: Good moderate crack with a super finish. Crux is the first 15 feet of the climb - which does yield well to finesse and no real grunting is necessary - although it does seem awkward to begin with. Climb this to the top of the little pinnacle. Then head up the steep, flakey but easy crack to the ledge to be rewarded with a super vista of Big Bear valley. The short blocky arete or the right edge seems like the appropriate finish to reach the two-bolt anchor.
content.location: Right slanting crack just left of the pine tree, followed by the rightmost easy looking flake crack (not the middle one which is 5.9 and poorly protected).
